the way I see it there are generally two
aspects of practicing the first is
getting your head and ear around a new
concept for example learning a scale at
first you're just gonna need to sit
there and figure it out until you don't
really need to think about it much once
you're there you're gonna want to put
the repetitions in so you don't need to

boring it doesn't usually require much
mental engagement so when I get to the
stage I'll usually get my reps in while
watching TV or something now the second
part of practicing is often overlooked
and is just as important this is taking
that new concept you've learned and
working on applying it in a practical
setting this is also usually the fun
part you're going to want to take your
skill and find a way to use
with a music that you love that could be
something like writing a piece of music
using the notes from it improvising with
it over a backing track or taking a song
that you like and seeing how it fits
within that scale you've got to find a
balance between these two aspects of
your practice and if you can't find a
way to connect these two things and you
need to re-evaluate what you're working
